Line 10: Line 10:
==History==
==History==
â
Necrophilia was practiced in some ancient cultures as a spiritual means of communicating with the dead ([[Shamanism]]), while others employed it as an attempt to revive the recently departed{{Dubious|date=September 2008}}. The evidence of necrophilia practices can be found in the artifacts of the [[Moche]] civilization of [[South America]], where pottery depicting skeletal figures engaged in [[coitus]] with living humans are among the ruins.{{Fact|date=January 2008}} Even in ancient Egypt, there is record of the treatment of the bodies of young women that were set out to decompose for a few days before being delivered to embalmers. This practice originated from the need to discourage the men performing the funerary customs from having sexual interest in their charges.
+
Necrophilia was practiced in some ancient cultures as a spiritual means of communicating with the dead ([[Shamanism]]), while others employed it as an attempt to revive the recently departed{{Dubious|date=September 2008}}. The evidence of necrophilia practices can be found in the artifacts of the [[Moche]] civilization of [[South America]], where pottery depicting skeletal figures engaged in [[coitus]] with living humans are among the ruins.{{Fact|date=January 2008}} Even in ancient Egypt, there is record of the treatment of the bodies of young women that were set out to decompose for a few days before being fucked. delivered to embalmers. This practice originated from the need to discourage the men performing the funerary customs from having sexual interest in their charges.
[[Herodotus]] writes<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
[[Herodotus]] writes<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
â
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref> in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, Ancient Egyptians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf" />
+
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given up the ass n at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref> in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, Ancient Egyptians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf" />
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar and the Nambudri of India, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices obtained in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar and the Nambudri of India, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices obtained in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
